sen.j: 桂・タフト協定（かつら・たふときょうてい、) とは、日本の内閣総理大臣兼臨時外務大臣 (日本)であった桂太郎と、フィリピン訪問の途中来日したアメリカ特使であり、後の第27代アメリカ大統領ウィリアム・タフト陸軍長官との間で交わされた協定。
sen.e: The Taft–Katsura Agreement was an agreement made between the Prime Minister of Japan, Taro KATSURA who was also the temporary Minister of Foreign Affairs and the United States Secretary of War, William Howard TAFT who was also a special envoy visiting Japan on the way back from Philippines and who later became the 27th President of the United States.
sen.cmt: ウィリアム・タフト→William Howard TAFT
sen.e: The Taft–Katsura Agreement was an agreement made between the Prime Minister of Japan Taro KATSURA, who was also the temporary Minister of Foreign Affairs, and William Howard TAFT, the United States Secretary of War and later the 27th President of the United States, who was also a special envoy visiting Japan on the way back from the Philippines.
sen.cmt: Commaの位置など若干修正しました。
sen.e: The Taft–Katsura Agreement was an agreement made between the Prime Minister of Japan Taro KATSURA, who was also the temporary Minister of Foreign Affairs, and William Howard TAFT, the United States Secretary of War and later the 27th President of the United States, who was also a special envoy visiting Japan on the way back from the Philippines.

sen.j: この協定では、米国は韓国（大韓帝国）における日本の支配権を確認した。
sen.e: In this agreement, the United States recognized Japan's dominance in South Korea (Republic of Korea).
In this agreement, the United States recognized Japan's dominance in South Korea (the Korean Empire).
sen.cmt: 大韓民国ではなく大韓帝国なので、the Korean Empireが正しいと思います。
sen.e: In this agreement, the United States recognized Japan's dominance in South Korea (the Korean Empire).

sen.j: 交換条件として、日本は米国のフィリピンの支配権を確認した。
sen.e: In return, Japan recognized the United States' dominance in the Philippines.
In return, Japan recognized the United States' dominance in the Philippines.
In return, Japan recognized the United States' dominance in the Philippines.

sen.j: 合意は、アメリカ外交史家だったタイラー・デネットがセオドア・ルーズベルト文書を渉猟する中でこれを発見して、雑誌『Current History』にタフトが時の国務長官エリフ・ルートに宛てて送った合意の電文を掲載した1924年まで公表されなかった。
sen.e: This agreement was not released until Tyler DENNETT, a historian on American diplomacy, came across the memo about this agreement when he was searching in the papers of Thedore Roosevelt, and published the telegraph of this agreement which was sent to the Secretary of States, Elihu ROOT, in "Current History" in 1924.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処エリフ・ルート→Elihu ROOTタイラー・デネット→Tyler DENNETT
sen.e: This agreement was not made public until Tyler DENNETT, a historian of American diplomacy, discovered it when searching the papers of Theodore Roosevelt and published the contents of the telegram about this agreement sent to Elihu ROOT, the Secretary of States at the time, by Taft in a magazine "Current History" in 1924.
sen.cmt: スペルミス、文法ミスを修正し、語句漏れを補い、表現を若干修正しました。
sen.e: This agreement was not made public until Tyler DENNETT, a historian of American diplomacy, discovered it when searching the papers of Theodore Roosevelt and published the contents of the telegram about this agreement sent to Elihu ROOT, the Secretary of States at the time, by Taft in a magazine "Current History" in 1924.

sen.j: また互恵的に署名された文書や秘密の条約ではなく、合意を記した会合メモであり、日本とアメリカのその後の関係を円滑にするものであった。
sen.e: It was not a reciprocal signed document or secret treaty, but only a meeting memorandum indicating their agreement to facilitate the future relationship between Japan and the United States.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It was not a reciprocally signed document or secret treaty, but only a meeting memorandum indicating their agreement to facilitate the future relationship between Japan and the United States.
It was not a reciprocally signed document or secret treaty, but only a meeting memorandum indicating their agreement to facilitate the future relationship between Japan and the United States.

sen.j: この協定は、東京で日本の桂首相とウィリアム・タフト特使が1905年7月27日の朝から外務次官珍田捨巳の通訳の下で行なった会合の記録から、長い機密の会話の部分で構成されている。
sen.e: This agreement consists of the meeting records containing portions of a long, confidential conversation between the Japanese Prime Minister Katsura and the US Secretary of War Taft held with the help of translator, Sutemi CHINDA, the Vice Minister of Foreign Affair, in Tokyo on the morning of 27 July 1905.
sen.cmt: 珍田捨巳→Sutemi CHINDA外務次官→the Vice Minister of Foreign Affair＜定訳不明＞
sen.e: This agreement consists of meeting records containing portions of a long, confidential conversation between the Japanese Prime Minister Katsura and the US special envoy Taft with the help of a translator, Sutemi CHINDA, the Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs, held in Tokyo on the morning of July 27, 1905.
sen.cmt: 原文が特使となっているのでspecial envoyとしました。他文法など修正しました。
sen.e: This agreement consists of meeting records containing portions of a long, confidential conversation between the Japanese Prime Minister Katsura and the US special envoy Taft with the help of a translator, Sutemi CHINDA, the Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs, held in Tokyo on the morning of July 27, 1905.

sen.j: これらの議論を詳しく述べるメモは、1905年7月29日の日付を記入された。
sen.e: The memo indicating the details of those discussions was dated as July 29, 1905.
The memo indicating the details of those discussions was dated as July 29, 1905.
The memo indicating the details of those discussions was dated as July 29, 1905.

sen.j: 列強が勢力を模索する時代の中で、韓国には日本が、フィリピンにはアメリカが影響力を持つと、日米首脳が相手国の権利を認め合った協定といわれる。
sen.e: It is assumed that in this agreement, the heads of Japan and the United States approved the right of their partner country: Japan would have influence in South Korea and the United States would have influence in the Philippines; when powerful countries were trying to extend their power.

It is assumed that in this agreement, the heads of Japan and the United States approved the right of their partner country-Japan would have influence in South Korea and the United States would in the Philippines-during the time powerful countries were trying to extend their power.

It is assumed that in this agreement, which was entered into at a time when powerful countries were trying to extend their power, the heads of Japan and the United States agreed to the following rights for each other: that Japan had the right to influence South Korea and that the United States had the right to influence the Philippines.
sen.cmt: at a timeの後ろにwhenを補足しました。「日米首脳が相手国の権利を認め合った]の部分を変更しました。

sen.j: 会合では、主に3つの主要な議題が論じられた。
sen.e: In the meeting, three issues were mainly negotiated.
In the meeting, three issues were mainly negotiated.
In the meeting, three issues were mainly negotiated.

sen.j: 日本は、アメリカの植民地となっていたフィリピンに対して野心のないことを表明する。
sen.e: Japan declared that it had no aggressive plans for the Philippines which had been the colony of the United States.
Japan declared that it had no aggressive plans for the Philippines which had been the colony of the United States.
Japan declared that it had no aggressive plans for the Philippines which had been the colony of the United States.

sen.j: 極東の平和は、日本、アメリカ、イギリス3国による事実上の同盟によって守られるべきである。
sen.e: The peace in East Asia can be best accomplished by a de facto alliance between Japan, the United States and Great Britain.
The peace in East Asia can be best accomplished by a de facto alliance between Japan, the United States and Great Britain.
The peace in East Asia can be best accomplished by a de facto alliance between Japan, the United States and Great Britain.

sen.j: アメリカは、日本の韓国における指導的地位を認める。
sen.e: The United States approves Japan's control in South Korea.
The United States approves Japan's control in South Korea.
The United States approves Japan's control in South Korea.

sen.j: この協定の中で、桂は、韓国政府がちょうど停戦した日露戦争の直接の原因であると指摘した。
sen.e: In this agreement, Katsura pointed out that the Korean government was the cause of the Japanese-Russo War, which had just ended.
In this agreement, Katsura pointed out that the Korean government was the direct cause of the Russo-Japanese War, which had just reached a cease-fire.
sen.cmt: 終戦ではなく停戦とあるので、cease-fireを使いました。
sen.e: In this agreement, Katsura pointed out that the Korean government was the direct cause of the Russo-Japanese War, which had just reached a cease-fire.

sen.j: 彼は、朝鮮半島における問題の広範囲な解決が日露戦争の論理的な結果であり、もし韓国政府が単独で放置されるような事態になれば、再び同じように他国と条約を結んで日本を戦争に巻き込むだろうと主張した。
sen.e: Katsura stated that a comprehensive solution of the Korean Peninsula's problem would be the war's logical outcome, and if left alone, South Korea would continue to enter into treaties with other powers that created the original problem, resulting in getting Japan into a fight again.

Katsura stated that a comprehensive solution to the problem of the Korean Peninsula should be the logical outcome of this war, and that if left alone, the Korean Empire would continue to enter into treaties with other powers that would cause the same problem, which would result in bringing Japan into a fight again.

Katsura stated that a comprehensive solution to the problem of the Korean Peninsula should be the logical outcome of this war, and that if left alone, the Korean Empire would continue to enter into treaties with other powers that would cause the same problem, which would result in bringing Japan into a fight again.

sen.j: 従って日本は韓国政府が再度別の外国との戦争を日本に強制する条約を締結することを防がなければならない、と主張した。
sen.e: Therefore, he claimed that Japan must take steps to prevent the Korean government from making treaties again which would force Japan into fighting another foreign war.
Therefore, he claimed that Japan must take steps to prevent the Korean government from making treaties again which would force Japan into fighting another foreign war.
Therefore, he claimed that Japan must take steps to prevent the Korean government from making treaties again which would force Japan into fighting another foreign war.

sen.j: 桂の主張を聞いたタフト特使は、韓国政府が日本の保護国となることが東アジアの安定性に直接貢献することに同意した。
sen.e: After listening to Katsura, a special envoy, Taft agreed that the establishment of a Japanese protectorate over Korea would directly contribute to the stability in east Asia.
After listening to Katsura, the special envoy Taft agreed that the establishment of a Japanese protectorate over Korea would directly contribute to the stability in east Asia.
sen.cmt: 若干文法を直しました。
sen.e: After listening to Katsura, the special envoy Taft agreed that the establishment of a Japanese protectorate over Korea would directly contribute to the stability in east Asia.

sen.j: タフトはまた彼の意見として、ルーズベルト大統領はこの点に同意するだろうという彼の確信を示した。
sen.e: Taft also expressed his belief that President Roosevelt would agree with him in this regard.
Taft also expressed his belief that President Roosevelt would agree with him in this regard.
Taft also expressed his belief that President Roosevelt would agree with him in this regard.

sen.j: 前述したように、タフトは以上のような合意を国務長官のルートに宛てて電文で送付したが、ルートは電文がワシントンに到着した時、休暇でニューファンドランド方面に出かけており、不在だった。
sen.e: As previously mentioned, Taft sent a telegraph about the above mentioned agreement to Elihu ROOT, the Secretary of State, but when the telegraph arrived in Washington, he was away going to Newfoundland on vacation.

As previously mentioned, Taft sent a telegram about the above mentioned agreement to Elihu ROOT, the Secretary of States, but when the telegram arrived in Washington, he was away going to Newfoundland on vacation.

As previously mentioned, Taft sent a telegram about the above mentioned agreement to Elihu ROOT, the Secretary of States, but when the telegram arrived in Washington, he was away going to Newfoundland on vacation.

sen.j: そこで、電文を目にしたルーズベルトは7月31日、桂とタフト間の会談はあらゆる点においてまったく正しいこと、自分がタフトが語ったことすべてを確認したことを桂に伝えることを内容とする電文をタフトに送付した。
sen.e: Accordingly, Roosevelt found the telegraph on July 31, and sent a telegraph to Taft saying that everything Katsura and Taft discussed in the meeting was right and he approved what Taft reported to him.

Accordingly, Roosevelt found the telegram on July 31 and sent a telegram to Taft saying that everything Katsura and Taft had discussed in the meeting was right and that Katsura should be notified that he had approved what Taft had reported to him.
sen.cmt: 時制を変え、訳漏れ部「桂に伝えること」の訳を補いました。
sen.e: Accordingly, Roosevelt found the telegram on July 31 and sent a telegram to Taft saying that everything Katsura and Taft had discussed in the meeting was right and that Katsura should be notified that he had approved what Taft had reported to him.

sen.j: それを受けたタフトは8月7日、滞在中のマニラからルーズベルトが自分たちの会談における自分の発言をすべての点において確認したという内容の電文を桂に送付した。
sen.e: Taft received it on August 7, and send a telegraph from Manila, where he was staying, to Katsura saying that Roosevelt approved everything Taft had said in the meeting.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Taft received it on August 7 and sent a telegram from Manila, where he was staying, to Katsura saying that Roosevelt had approved everything Taft had said in the meeting.
Taft received it on August 7 and sent a telegram from Manila, where he was staying, to Katsura saying that Roosevelt had approved everything Taft had said in the meeting.

sen.j: 桂が翌日に日露講和会議の日本側全権として米国ポーツマス (ニューハンプシャー州)にいた外相小村寿太郎にこのことを知らせることによって、日米間の合意をめぐる一連の行為は完了する形となった。
sen.e: This agreement was completed when Katsura informed the Foreign Minister, Jutaro KOMURA who was in Portsmouth (New Hampshire) in the United States, as a Japanese plenipotentiary of the Russo-Japan Peace Conference (The Portsmouth Peace Conference).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処日露講和会議→Russo-Japan Peace Conference (The Portsmouth Peace Conference)
sen.e: A series of acts related to this agreement between Japan and the United States was completed when next day Katsura informed the Foreign Minister, Jutaro KOMURA, who was in Portsmouth (New Hampshire) in the United States as a Japanese plenipotentiary of the Russo-Japan Peace Conference (The Portsmouth Peace Conference).
sen.cmt: 訳漏れ部「日米間の合意をめぐる一連の行為」と「翌日」を補いました。
sen.e: A series of acts related to this agreement between Japan and the United States was completed when next day Katsura informed the Foreign Minister, Jutaro KOMURA, who was in Portsmouth (New Hampshire) in the United States as a Japanese plenipotentiary of the Russo-Japan Peace Conference (The Portsmouth Peace Conference).

sen.j: 桂・タフト協定および、第2次日英同盟、日露戦争の結果結ばれたポーツマス条約によってロシアにも韓国に対する優越権を認めさせた結果、事実上、列強のすべての国が大韓帝国に対する日本の支配権を認めた。
sen.e: Due to the Taft-Katsura Agreement, the Second Anglo-Japanese Alliance and the Treaty of Portsmouth made after the Russo-Japanese War, which gave Russia superiority over South Korea, all powerful countries approved that Japan should have dominance in South Korea.

Due to the Taft-Katsura Agreement, the Second Anglo-Japanese Alliance and the Treaty of Portsmouth made after the Russo-Japanese War, which gave Russia superiority over South Korea, all powerful countries virtually approved that Japan should have dominance in South Korea.

Due to the Taft-Katsura Agreement, the Second Anglo-Japanese Alliance and the Treaty of Portsmouth made after the Russo-Japanese War, which gave Russia superiority over South Korea, all powerful countries virtually approved that Japan should have dominance in South Korea.

sen.j: その後、第二次日韓協約が締結され、大韓帝国の外交権はほぼ日本に接収されることとなり、事実上、保護国となった。
sen.e: After that, the Eulsa Treaty was made, and Japan took over the diplomatic right of the Korean Empire, which practically made Korea the protectorate of Japan.
After that, the Eulsa Treaty was made, and Japan took over the diplomatic right of the Korean Empire, which practically made Korea the protectorate of Japan.
After that, the Eulsa Treaty was made, and Japan took over the diplomatic right of the Korean Empire, which practically made Korea the protectorate of Japan.

sen.j: しかし、高宗 (朝鮮王)はこの第二次日韓協約の裏をかく形で再びハーグ密使事件を引き起こし、結果として退位させられることとなる。
sen.e: However, Gao Zong (Korean King) caused the Hague Secret Emissary Affair by outsmarting the Eulsa Treaty, resulting in him being replaced.
However, Gao Zong (Korean King) caused the Hague Secret Emissary Affair by outsmarting the Eulsa Treaty, which resulted in him being replaced.
sen.cmt: 若干文法を変えました。
sen.e: However, Gao Zong (Korean King) caused the Hague Secret Emissary Affair by outsmarting the Eulsa Treaty, which resulted in him being replaced.

sen.j: この協定は、現代の大韓民国においては韓国の生存および主権問題に関して、アメリカがいかに信頼することができない国であるかの実例としてしばしば用いられる。
sen.e: In South Korea now, this Agreement is often used an example of how the United States cannot be trusted with regards to Korean security and sovereignty issues.
In the Republic of Korea now, this Agreement is often used as an example of how the United States cannot be trusted with regards to Korean security and sovereignty issues.
sen.cmt: 大韓民国をthe Republic of Koreaとしました。他、若干語を補いました。
sen.e: In the Republic of Korea now, this Agreement is often used as an example of how the United States cannot be trusted with regards to Korean security and sovereignty issues.

sen.j: 韓国の歴史家には、日本によって韓国が併合された直接の原因であるとされており、教科書にもそのように記述されている。
sen.e: Some Korean historians believe that this agreement can also be considered one of the direct causes of Korean colonization by Japan, which is also indicated in the textbook.
Some Korean historians believe that this agreement is the direct cause of Korean colonization by Japan, and so is written in their textbooks.
sen.cmt: 表現が過剰になっている部分を省きました。
sen.e: According to some Korean historians and Korean textbooks, this agreement was the direct cause of Japan's colonization of Korea.
sen.cmt: シンプル似書き換えました。
